elements.content: The self-assembly reaction of arylhydrazones of β-diketones (AHBD), namely 2-[2-(2,4-dioxopentan-3-ylidene)hydrazinyl]benzenesulfonic acid (H2L1) and 2-[2-(4,4-dimethyl-2,6-dioxocyclohexylidene)hydrazinyl]benzenesulfonic acid (H2L2), with sodium or potassium hydroxides in MeOH/H2O (1/1, v/v) produces a series of coordination compounds, [Na3(μ3-HL1)2(μ4-HL1)(μ-H2O)(H2O)2] n (1), [Na2(HL1)2(μ-H2O)2(H2O)4]·4H2O (2), [Na(HL2)(μ-H2O)(H2O)2] n ·nH2O (3), [K(μ4-HL1)(μ3-H2O)] n (4), and [K(μ4-HL2)(H2O)] n (5), which include the one-dimensional (3), two-dimensional (2D) (1, 4), and three-dimensional (3D) (5) coordination polymers, as well as the zero-dimensional dimer (2). Compounds 1–5 were isolated as air stable crystalline solids and characterized by IR, 1H, and 13C{1H} NMR spectroscopy, elemental, differential thermal, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The latter shows that the monodeprotonated HL1– (L = L1, L2) anions act as multiple O-donors through the sulfonate and carbonyl groups and are also capable of simultaneously bridging three and/or four metal cations (in 1, 4, and 5), thus giving rise to the intricate 2D and 3D coordination networks. Their topological analysis reveals the trinodal 3,4,7-connected (in 4) and pentanodal 3,4-connected (in 1) underlying 2D nets with novel types of topologies, as well as the uninodal 4-connected 3D framework with the sra (SrAl2) topology (in 5).

Compounds 1-5 were isolated as air stable crystalline solids and characterized by IR, 1H, and 13C{1H} NMR spectroscopy, elemental, differential thermal, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The latter shows that the monodeprotonated HL1- (L = L1, L2) anions act as multiple O-donors through the sulfonate and carbonyl groups and are also capable of simultaneously bridging three and/or four metal cations (in 1, 4, and 5), thus giving rise to the intricate 2D and 3D coordination networks. Their topological analysis reveals the trinodal 3,4,7-connected (in 4) and pentanodal 3,4-connected (in 1) underlying 2D nets with novel types of topologies, as well as the uninodal 4-connected 3D framework with the sra (SrAl2) topology (in 5).

elements.content: Alkali metal ions are valuable metal sources in crystal engineering of solid-state coordination polymers, since they can adopt versatile coordination geometries that are easily regulated by the selection of appropriate organic building blocks. The s-block metal ions also differ significantly in their radius and electronegativity, thus leading to a wide variety of possible coordination numbers and often resulting in metal–organic networks with hardly predictable architectures. In contrast to the extensive research on transition metal coordination polymers, the investigation of polymeric networks incorporating alkali metal ions has remained a relatively less-explored area. This is however in some contradiction with the fact that many s-metal–organic compounds are widely used as building blocks in supramolecular chemistry, apart from being present in diverse natural environments and living systems.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Alkali metal ions are valuable metal sources in crystal engineering of solid-state coordination polymers, since they can adopt versatile coordination geometries that are easily regulated by the selection of appropriate organic building blocks. The s-block metal ions also differ significantly in their radius and electronegativity, thus leading to a wide variety of possible coordination numbers and often resulting in metal-organic networks with hardly predictable architectures. In contrast to the extensive research on transition metal coordination polymers, the investigation of polymeric networks incorporating alkali metal ions has remained a relatively less-explored area. This is however in some contradiction with the fact that many s-metal-organic compounds are widely used as building blocks in supramolecular chemistry, apart from being present in diverse natural environments and living systems.

elements.content: On the other hand, arylhydrazones of β-diketones (hereafter denoted as AHBD) and the metal complexes therefrom have attracted attention due to their high synthetic potential in organic and inorganic chemistry and some interesting properties (e.g., as semiconductors, ionophores, analytical reagents, materials for optical storage, spin-coating films, liquid crystals, and self-assembled layers). The aqueous solubility of the AHBD compounds has particular importance for catalytic or biological applications where water is used as a solvent and/or reactant. The modification of AHBD building blocks by introducing a hydrophilic functionality such as the sulfonic acid group represents a common strategy to increase water solubility of the ligands and the resulting coordination compounds. Given the fact that −SO3H groups can exhibit a variety of coordination modes toward s-block metal ions, the use of organic building blocks based on the hydrazones of β-diketones functionalized with benzenesulfonic acid represents a valuable approach. Besides, its exploration can also be justified by the limited number of the reported alkali metal coordination compounds bearing AHBD ligands.

elements.content: Hence, the main objective of the present work consisted in probing the coordination behavior of 2-[2-(2,4-dioxopentan-3-ylidene)hydrazinyl]benzenesulfonic acid (H2L1) and 2-[2-(4,4-dimethyl-2,6-dioxocyclohexylidene)hydrazinyl]benzenesulfonic acid (H2L2) ligands (Scheme ) toward sodium and potassium ions, aiming at the synthesis of coordination polymers with unexpected topologies. We thus report herein the easy self-assembly synthesis, full characterization, and structural features of a new series of Na and K coordination polymers driven by benzenesulfonic acid functionalized hydrazones of β-diketones.

elements.content: All chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used as received, except for H2L1 and H2L2 that were prepared by published methods. Infrared spectra (4000–400 cm–1) were recorded on a BIO-RAD FTS 3000MX instrument in KBr pellets. C, H, and N elemental analyses were carried out by the Microanalytical Service of the Instituto Superior Técnico. The 1H and 13C{1H} NMR spectra were recorded at ambient temperature on a Bruker Avance II + 300 (UltraShield Magnet) spectrometer operating at 300.130 and 75.468 MHz for proton and carbon-13, respectively. The chemical shifts are reported in ppm, using tetramethylsilane as the internal reference. All synthetic work was performed in air and at room temperature (r.t. is ∼25 °C). Differential thermal analyses were run on a Perkin-Elmer STA 6000 Instrument in air. The crystalline samples were heated at the rate of 10 °C/min in the 35–800 °C temperature range.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used as received, except for H2L1 and H2L2 that were prepared by published methods. Infrared spectra (4000-400 cm-1) were recorded on a BIO-RAD FTS 3000MX instrument in KBr pellets. C, H, and N elemental analyses were carried out by the Microanalytical Service of the Instituto Superior Técnico. The 1H and 13C{1H} NMR spectra were recorded at ambient temperature on a Bruker Avance II + 300 (UltraShield Magnet) spectrometer operating at 300.130 and 75.468 MHz for proton and carbon-13, respectively. The chemical shifts are reported in ppm, using tetramethylsilane as the internal reference. All synthetic work was performed in air and at room temperature (r.t. is ~25 °C). Differential thermal analyses were run on a Perkin-Elmer STA 6000 Instrument in air. The crystalline samples were heated at the rate of 10 °C/min in the 35-800 °C temperature range.

elements.content: To a MeOH/H2O solution (25 mL, 1/1, v/v) of ligand [H2L1 (1.0 mmol, 284 mg for 1, 2, and 4) or H2L2 (1.0 mmol, 324 mg for 3 and 5)] alkali metal hydroxide [NaOH (2.0 mmol, 80 mg for 1; 1.0 mmol, 40 mg for 2 and 3) or KOH (1.0 mmol, 56 mg for 4 and 5)] was added. The obtained mixture was stirred for 5 min and left for slow evaporation in air at r.t. Colorless (1) or yellow (2–5) crystals were formed in 5 d (including those of X-ray quality), whereafter they were filtered off and dried in air to give compounds 1–5.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and Analytical Data

To a MeOH/H2O solution (25 mL, 1/1, v/v) of ligand [H2L1 (1.0 mmol, 284 mg for 1, 2, and 4) or H2L2 (1.0 mmol, 324 mg for 3 and 5)] alkali metal hydroxide [NaOH (2.0 mmol, 80 mg for 1; 1.0 mmol, 40 mg for 2 and 3) or KOH (1.0 mmol, 56 mg for 4 and 5)] was added. The obtained mixture was stirred for 5 min and left for slow evaporation in air at r.t. Colorless (1) or yellow (2-5) crystals were formed in 5 d (including those of X-ray quality), whereafter they were filtered off and dried in air to give compounds 1-5.

Crystals were immersed in cryo-oil, mounted in a Nylon loop and measured at a temperature of 150 K (293 K for 4). Intensity data were collected using a Bruker AXS-KAPPA APEX II diffractometer with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073) radiation. Data were collected using omega scans of 0.5° per frame and full sphere of data were obtained. Cell parameters were retrieved using Bruker SMART software and refined using Bruker SAINT on all observed reflections. Absorption corrections were applied using SADABS. Structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 and refined with SHELXL-97. Calculations were performed using the WinGX, version 1.80.03. Hydrogen atoms were inserted in calculated positions, except those of coordinated and free water molecules in every compound, which were located in the difference Fourier synthesis but were included in the final refinements at positions calculated from the geometry of the molecules using the riding model, with isotropic vibration parameters. The H2O molecule in 5 was disordered over two sites and refined with the use of PART instruction. The occupancies of O6A and O6B refined to a ratio of 79 and 21%. Least square refinements with anisotropic thermal motion parameters for all the nonhydrogen atoms and isotropic for most of the remaining atoms were employed. Crystallographic details are listed in Table .

Refinement Details for X-ray Analysis

Crystals were immersed in cryo-oil, mounted in a Nylon loop and measured at a temperature of 150 K (293 K for 4). Intensity data were collected using a Bruker AXS-KAPPA APEX II diffractometer with graphite monochromatic Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073) radiation. Data were collected using omega scans of 0.5° per frame and full sphere of data were obtained. Cell parameters were retrieved using Bruker SMART software and refined using Bruker SAINT on all observed reflections. Absorption corrections were applied using SADABS. Structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 and refined with SHELXL-97. Calculations were performed using the WinGX, version 1.80.03. Hydrogen atoms were inserted in calculated positions, except those of coordinated and free water molecules in every compound, which were located in the difference Fourier synthesis but were included in the final refinements at positions calculated from the geometry of the molecules using the riding model, with isotropic vibration parameters. The H2O molecule in 5 was disordered over two sites and refined with the use of PART instruction. The occupancies of O6A and O6B refined to a ratio of 79 and 21%. Least square refinements with anisotropic thermal motion parameters for all the nonhydrogen atoms and isotropic for most of the remaining atoms were employed. Crystallographic details are listed in Table .

The simple self-assembly reactions of H2L1 or H2L2 with NaOH or KOH, in a methanol–water (1/1, v/v) solution at r.t., result in a series of structurally distinct coordination compounds, [Na2(HL1)2(μ-H2O)2(H2O)4]·4H2O (2), [Na(HL2)(μ-H2O)(H2O)2] n ·nH2O (3), [K(μ4-HL1)(μ3-H2O)] n (4), and [K(μ4-HL2)(H2O)] n (5), which include the one-dimensional (1D) (3), two-dimensional (2D) (1, 4), and three-dimensional (3D) (5) coordination polymers, as well as the zero-dimensional (0D) dimer (2). For the synthesis of 2–5, the AHBD ligands and the corresponding alkali metal hydroxide were typically used in the 1:1 molar ratio, while the reaction of H2L1 with NaOH taken in the 1:2 molar ratio furnished 1. Curiously, in the cases of 2–5, if the AHBD:alkali metal hydroxide molar ratio is changed to 1:2, the same products were obtained. All the compounds 1–5 were isolated in good yields (51–57%) as colorless (1) or yellow (2–5) crystals upon slow evaporation of the reaction mixtures in air at ∼25 °C. The molecular structures of 1–5 were determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction and supported by IR, 1H, and 13C{1H} NMR spectroscopy, elemental, and differential thermal analysis. It should be mentioned that the attempts to crystallize analogous derivatives using other alkali and alkaline-earth metal hydroxides [e.g., LiOH, CsOH, Mg(OH)2, Ca(OH)2] were not successful.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

The simple self-assembly reactions of H2L1 or H2L2 with NaOH or KOH, in a methanol-water (1/1, v/v) solution at r.t., result in a series of structurally distinct coordination compounds, [Na2(HL1)2(μ-H2O)2(H2O)4]⋅4H2O (2), [Na(HL2)(μ-H2O)(H2O)2] n ⋅nH2O (3), [K(μ4-HL1)(μ3-H2O)] n  (4), and [K(μ4-HL2)(H2O)] n  (5), which include the one-dimensional (1D) (3), two-dimensional (2D) (1, 4), and three-dimensional (3D) (5) coordination polymers, as well as the zero-dimensional (0D) dimer (2). For the synthesis of 2-5, the AHBD ligands and the corresponding alkali metal hydroxide were typically used in the 1:1 molar ratio, while the reaction of H2L1 with NaOH taken in the 1:2 molar ratio furnished 1. Curiously, in the cases of 2-5, if the AHBD:alkali metal hydroxide molar ratio is changed to 1:2, the same products were obtained. All the compounds 1-5 were isolated in good yields (51-57%) as colorless (1) or yellow (2-5) crystals upon slow evaporation of the reaction mixtures in air at ~25 °C. The molecular structures of 1-5 were determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction and supported by IR, 1H, and 13C{1H} NMR spectroscopy, elemental, and differential thermal analysis. It should be mentioned that the attempts to crystallize analogous derivatives using other alkali and alkaline-earth metal hydroxides [e.g., LiOH, CsOH, Mg(OH)2, Ca(OH)2] were not successful.

elements.content: In spite of applying a strong base in the described syntheses, the so-named resonance-assisted hydrogen bonds (RAHB), which combine a hydrazo hydrogen with the SO3 and CO moieties, are still present in all the compounds. In comparison to the ligands, the ν(NH) IR and δ(s, 1H, N–H) NMR signals of the NH group are shifted as follows: 3147 cm–1 and 14.71 ppm for H2L1 versus 3114 (1, 2) or 3116 (4) cm–1, and 14.96 (1), 14.83 (2), or 14.72 (4) ppm; 2954 cm–1 and 15.28 ppm for H2L2 versus 2870 (3) or 2895 (5) cm–1, and 15.32 (3) or 15.30 (5) ppm.

elements.content:
The numbers indicate the corresponding extensions of polymeric motifs.

Description of the Crystal Structures

The compounds bear Na-aqua (1–3) and K-aqua (4 and 5) motifs, the positive charge of which is balanced by monodeprotonated HL– ligands, acting in different coordination modes (see Scheme and Figure ). They form dimeric species (2) or 1D (3), 2D (1 and 4), or 3D (5) polymers, and in all the structures HL– preserves the strong RAHB, linking the NH-moieties of the hydrazone unit to both an O-carbonyl and the O-sulfonate groups. In all complexes, the metal cations are in all O environments. In 2 and 3, with Na–O separations in the 2.3021(18) – 2.6022(15) Å range, the Na atoms are in octahedral locations which are highly distorted, as measured by the octahedral angle variances (OAV) and quadratic elongations (OQE) which assume values of 113 and 1.036 for the former and of 45.26 and 1.016 for the latter. In compound 1, with three nonequivalent sodium cations, the geometries around the metals are even more distorted with OAV and OQE adopting values of 318 and 1.109 for Na1 and 100 and 1.03 for Na2; the geometry around Na3, however, is better described as a trigonal bipyramid (τ5 = 0.47), where the Na–O distances vary from 2.268(2) to 2.561(2) Å, although higher coordination numbers cannot be disregarded in view of two additional elongated interactions [Na3–O23i, 3.002(3) Å; Na3–O33ii, 3.177(2) Å]. Expectedly, the bigger potassium cation in 4 and 5 is 9- and 8-coordinated, respectively, with the K–O bond lengths ranging from 2.598(7) to 3.128(8) Å.

elements.content: As a result of imposed geometry constrictions perhaps due to the noncoordination of the hydrazine moieties, the HL– ligands present considerable planarity that may be weighed up (Table S1 of the ) by the M–O–S–C torsion angles, in the |132.2(1)°| – |155.6(3)°| range, and the M–O–C–CN torsion angles, which adopt values from |111.4(3)°| to |174.7(4)°|. Taking into consideration the least-squares planes defined by the aromatic rings (plane A), the metal cations are moved away from these planes by 0.322–0.813 Å. In addition, the quaternary carbon C10 in 3 is displaced 1.159 Å away from plane A and on the same side as the metal cation; in 5, that atom is 1.395 Å away from that plane but on the opposite side of that of the metal. Moreover, in compounds with a flexible OCCmethyl (viz. 1, 2, and 4), the least-squares planes for these groups (plane B) are slightly twisted relative to plane A (by 5.60–13.08°).

elements.content: The M–O bond dimensions in compounds 2–5 differ, depending whether the oxygen atoms belong to the sulfonate or to the ketone groups, with the latter [2.318(3)–2.815(2) Å] shorter than the former [2.462(3)–3.063(2) Å]; in 1, the SO3 linkage diversity (mono-, bi-, or even tridentate) precludes any trend in this parameter. In all the compounds, the bond distances of 1.300(2)–1.311(3) Å for the N–N hydrazine groups suggest their double bond character.

elements.content: While intermolecular π···π stacking interactions appear not to be important in these structures, CH···π contacts are relevant in 1, 3, and 4 and involve methyl (in 1 and 4) or aromatic groups (in 3) as donors and neighboring phenyl rings as acceptors. In polymer 1, the minimum value of 2.570 Å is unusually strong and is related to the stacking disposition of the organic ligands.

elements.content: In spite of being constructed from rather similar building blocks and alkali metal ions, the obtained coordination polymers 1, 3, 4, and 5 possess very distinct metal–organic networks. Thus, the infinite 1D zigzag chains in [Na(HL2)(μ-H2O)(H2O)2] n ·nH2O (3) are driven by μ-H2O linkers that assemble the adjacent [Na(HL2)(H2O)2] units (Figure ). On the contrary, in the related potassium compound [K(μ4-HL2)(H2O)] n (5) the water molecule only acts as a terminal ligand, while the μ4-HL2 moiety simultaneously binds four K1 atoms, giving rise to the formation of a 3D framework structure (Figure a). This is composed of 1D tubular chain motifs (Figure b), generated via the linkage of K1 atoms by the μ3-sulfonate groups of μ4-HL2, which are sewed into the 3D network through the repeating K1–O4 and K1–O5 interactions between the metal atoms and CO groups of μ4-HL2. A different 2D network (Figure a) is observed in [K(μ4-HL1)(μ3-H2O)] n (4), wherein the 1D tubular chain [K(μ4-HL1)] n motifs (Figure b) are held together by multiple interactions with μ3-H2O moieties, furnishing the ladderlike metal–organic sheets. An even more complex 2D architecture (Figure , panels a and b) is found in a related sodium derivative [Na3(μ3-HL1)2(μ4-HL1)(μ-H2O)(H2O)2] n (1). The intricate character of this bilayered network is governed by the presence of three structurally distinct types of μ3- or μ4-HL1 ligands and three symmetry nonequivalent Na atoms, in addition to μ-H2O linkers.
elements.clean_text:
Comparative Description of Metal-Organic Networks

In spite of being constructed from rather similar building blocks and alkali metal ions, the obtained coordination polymers 1, 3, 4, and 5 possess very distinct metal-organic networks. Thus, the infinite 1D zigzag chains in [Na(HL2)(μ-H2O)(H2O)2] n ⋅nH2O (3) are driven by μ-H2O linkers that assemble the adjacent [Na(HL2)(H2O)2] units (Figure ). On the contrary, in the related potassium compound [K(μ4-HL2)(H2O)] n  (5) the water molecule only acts as a terminal ligand, while the μ4-HL2 moiety simultaneously binds four K1 atoms, giving rise to the formation of a 3D framework structure (Figure a). This is composed of 1D tubular chain motifs (Figure b), generated via the linkage of K1 atoms by the μ3-sulfonate groups of μ4-HL2, which are sewed into the 3D network through the repeating K1-O4 and K1-O5 interactions between the metal atoms and CO groups of μ4-HL2. A different 2D network (Figure a) is observed in [K(μ4-HL1)(μ3-H2O)] n  (4), wherein the 1D tubular chain [K(μ4-HL1)] n  motifs (Figure b) are held together by multiple interactions with μ3-H2O moieties, furnishing the ladderlike metal-organic sheets. An even more complex 2D architecture (Figure , panels a and b) is found in a related sodium derivative [Na3(μ3-HL1)2(μ4-HL1)(μ-H2O)(H2O)2] n  (1). The intricate character of this bilayered network is governed by the presence of three structurally distinct types of μ3- or μ4-HL1 ligands and three symmetry nonequivalent Na atoms, in addition to μ-H2O linkers.

elements.content: To get further insight into the structure of double 2D layers in 1, we have performed its topological analysis with TOPOS, following the concept of the simplified underlying net. Thus, by reducing the μ3-HL1, μ4-HL1, and μ-H2O moieties to their centroids and omitting the terminal H2O (O10, O20) ligands, the network of 1 can be described as an underlying net (Figure , panels c and d) constructed from the 4-connected Na1, Na2, Na3, and μ4-HL1 (S2) nodes, the 3-connected μ3-HL1 (S1, S3) nodes, and the 2-connected μ-H2O linkers (O30). The topological analysis of the resulting underlying net furnishes a pentanodal 3,4-connected network with a new topology described by the point symbol of (3.42.52.7)(3.82)(32.42.5.6)2(42.6.82.10)(42.6), wherein the notations (3.42.52.7), (3.82), (32.42.5.6), (42.6.82.10), and (42.6) correspond to the μ4-HL1 (S2), μ3-HL1 (S1), Na1/Na2 (topologically equivalent), Na3, and μ3-HL1 (S3) nodes, respectively. The undocumented character of the present topology has been confirmed by the search in different databases. Although a few pentanodal networks have recently been reported, these are typically observed in 3D coordination polymers.

Topological Analysis

Compound [Na3(μ3-HL1)2(μ4-HL1)(μ-H2O)(H2O)2] n  (1)

To get further insight into the structure of double 2D layers in 1, we have performed its topological analysis with TOPOS, following the concept of the simplified underlying net. Thus, by reducing the μ3-HL1, μ4-HL1, and μ-H2O moieties to their centroids and omitting the terminal H2O (O10, O20) ligands, the network of 1 can be described as an underlying net (Figure , panels c and d) constructed from the 4-connected Na1, Na2, Na3, and μ4-HL1 (S2) nodes, the 3-connected μ3-HL1 (S1, S3) nodes, and the 2-connected μ-H2O linkers (O30). The topological analysis of the resulting underlying net furnishes a pentanodal 3,4-connected network with a new topology described by the point symbol of (3.42.52.7)(3.82)(32.42.5.6)2(42.6.82.10)(42.6), wherein the notations (3.42.52.7), (3.82), (32.42.5.6), (42.6.82.10), and (42.6) correspond to the μ4-HL1 (S2), μ3-HL1 (S1), Na1/Na2 (topologically equivalent), Na3, and μ3-HL1 (S3) nodes, respectively. The undocumented character of the present topology has been confirmed by the search in different databases. Although a few pentanodal networks have recently been reported, these are typically observed in 3D coordination polymers.

elements.content: By adopting the above-mentioned strategy, we have also simplified the 2D network of 4 and performed its topological analysis. Thus, after reducing the μ4-HL1 and μ3-H2O moieties to their centroids, the resulting underlying net (Figure , panels c and d) is composed of the 7-connected K2, 4-connected μ4-HL1, and 3-connected μ3-H2O nodes. This trinodal 3,4,7-connected net features a novel type of topology with the point symbol of (412.69)(43)(46), wherein the notations (412.69), (43), and (46) are those of the K2, μ3-H2O, and μ4-HL1 nodes, respectively. Other topological types of 3,4,7-connected 2D networks were also described.

elements.content: The differential thermal analysis of 1–5 reveals several thermal effects within the 35–800 °C temperature range (Figure S1 and Table S3 of the ). The compounds 1 and 2 are thermally stable until 100 °C, and then the endothermic process in the 100–146 °C (100–142 °C for 2) range with a maximum at 137 °C (114 °C for 2) and overall mass loss of ca. 5% (2% for 2) occurs, corresponding to elimination of three coordinated and one crystallization water molecule in 1 and 2, respectively. In the second step, the HL1 ligand is partially destructed with an endothermic peak at 331 and 318 °C and with 21 and 11% weight loss for 1 and 2, respectively. After the elimination of crystallization and coordinated H2O molecules in the 67–100 °C for the 3 (93–113 °C for 4) range, the compounds 3 and 4 are thermally stable until 271 and 238 °C, when an endothermic decomposition occurs with the maximum mass loss at 301 and 267 °C, respectively. The thermal analysis of 5 shows five consecutive steps (Table S3 of the ). The first one, in the 77–105 °C range, with a strong and sharp DTG peak at 92 °C, most probably concerns the vigorous elimination of a hydrate water molecule. In the second and third steps, no pronounced weight changes were observed at 116–147 and 147–204 °C, respectively. The fourth and fifth steps of the decomposition occur with a mass loss of 7 and 18% in the 245–300 and 306–429 °C temperature intervals, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Differential Thermal Analysis

The differential thermal analysis of 1-5 reveals several thermal effects within the 35-800 °C temperature range (Figure S1 and Table S3 of the ). The compounds 1 and 2 are thermally stable until 100 °C, and then the endothermic process in the 100-146 °C (100-142 °C for 2) range with a maximum at 137 °C (114 °C for 2) and overall mass loss of ca. 5% (2% for 2) occurs, corresponding to elimination of three coordinated and one crystallization water molecule in 1 and 2, respectively. In the second step, the HL1 ligand is partially destructed with an endothermic peak at 331 and 318 °C and with 21 and 11% weight loss for 1 and 2, respectively. After the elimination of crystallization and coordinated H2O molecules in the 67-100 °C for the 3 (93-113 °C for 4) range, the compounds 3 and 4 are thermally stable until 271 and 238 °C, when an endothermic decomposition occurs with the maximum mass loss at 301 and 267 °C, respectively. The thermal analysis of 5 shows five consecutive steps (Table S3 of the ). The first one, in the 77-105 °C range, with a strong and sharp DTG peak at 92 °C, most probably concerns the vigorous elimination of a hydrate water molecule. In the second and third steps, no pronounced weight changes were observed at 116-147 and 147-204 °C, respectively. The fourth and fifth steps of the decomposition occur with a mass loss of 7 and 18% in the 245-300 and 306-429 °C temperature intervals, respectively.

elements.content: In the present study, we have shown that the benzenesulfonic acid functionalized hydrazones of β-diketones H2L1 and H2L2 are versatile building blocks toward the design of structurally distinct sodium and potassium coordination polymers, the architecture of which is significantly affected by the type of AHBD ligand and/or alkali metal. Thus, the resulting compounds vary from the 1D zigzag chains in 3, the intricate 2D bilayers in 1, and ladderlike sheets in 4, to the 3D framework in 5. Although the uninodal 4-connected network of 5 adopts the rather common sra (SrAl2) topology, the analysis of underlying nets in 1 and 4 allowed the identification of novel types of topologies in their pentanodal 3,4-connected and trinodal 3,4,7-connected 2D networks, respectively, which are driven by the μ3-HL1 and/or μ4-HL1 nodes and bridging water ligands acting as nodes or linkers. Hence, the current work also contributes to the identification and classification of coordination polymers with new topologies.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In the present study, we have shown that the benzenesulfonic acid functionalized hydrazones of β-diketones H2L1 and H2L2 are versatile building blocks toward the design of structurally distinct sodium and potassium coordination polymers, the architecture of which is significantly affected by the type of AHBD ligand and/or alkali metal. Thus, the resulting compounds vary from the 1D zigzag chains in 3, the intricate 2D bilayers in 1, and ladderlike sheets in 4, to the 3D framework in 5. Although the uninodal 4-connected network of 5 adopts the rather common sra (SrAl2) topology, the analysis of underlying nets in 1 and 4 allowed the identification of novel types of topologies in their pentanodal 3,4-connected and trinodal 3,4,7-connected 2D networks, respectively, which are driven by the μ3-HL1 and/or μ4-HL1 nodes and bridging water ligands acting as nodes or linkers. Hence, the current work also contributes to the identification and classification of coordination polymers with new topologies.

Compound [K(μ<sub>4</sub>-HL<sup>2</sup>)(H<sub>2</sub>O)]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>5</bold>)

After eliminating terminal H2O ligands and contracting μ4-HL2 moieties to their centroids, the structure of 5 can be considered as an underlying 3D net (Figure c) composed of the topologically equivalent 4-connected K1 and μ4-HL2 nodes. The analysis aided by the TOPOS reveals a uninodal framework with the point symbol of (42.63.8) and the sra (SrAl2) topology, according to the RCSR classification.

Differential Thermal Analysis

The differential thermal analysis of 1–5 reveals several thermal effects within the 35–800 °C temperature range (Figure S1 and Table S3 of the ). The compounds 1 and 2 are thermally stable until 100 °C, and then the endothermic process in the 100–146 °C (100–142 °C for 2) range with a maximum at 137 °C (114 °C for 2) and overall mass loss of ca. 5% (2% for 2) occurs, corresponding to elimination of three coordinated and one crystallization water molecule in 1 and 2, respectively. In the second step, the HL1 ligand is partially destructed with an endothermic peak at 331 and 318 °C and with 21 and 11% weight loss for 1 and 2, respectively. After the elimination of crystallization and coordinated H2O molecules in the 67–100 °C for the 3 (93–113 °C for 4) range, the compounds 3 and 4 are thermally stable until 271 and 238 °C, when an endothermic decomposition occurs with the maximum mass loss at 301 and 267 °C, respectively. The thermal analysis of 5 shows five consecutive steps (Table S3 of the ). The first one, in the 77–105 °C range, with a strong and sharp DTG peak at 92 °C, most probably concerns the vigorous elimination of a hydrate water molecule. In the second and third steps, no pronounced weight changes were observed at 116–147 and 147–204 °C, respectively. The fourth and fifth steps of the decomposition occur with a mass loss of 7 and 18% in the 245–300 and 306–429 °C temperature intervals, respectively.
